_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1) Accidental release prevention and Emergency response policies

In this facility, we use isobutane and isopentane which are considered flammable by the EPA. The same properties that make these materials valuable as blowing agents in our manufacturing processes also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions when handling them. These precautions are in place to prevent the unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to the health of our employees, and to reduce the threat to members of the nearby community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle isobutane, isopentane and ethane. This combined with the safety devices inherent in the design, the safe handling procedures that we use, and the training of our employees helps insure the safety of our employees and of the surrounding community. Our emergency response program is meant to comply with the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Law (Hazardous Materials Release Response Plans and Inventory Act). FP International's response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.  

2) Stationary source and regulated substance handled

A) At our Thornton facility, FP International uses recycled polystyrene in manufacturing our product. In the process to make foamed foamed polystyrene, isobutane and isopentane blowing agents are injected into the polymer melt during the extrusion processes.  Three storage tanks of 7600, 5762 and 2200 gallon capacity are used to store isobutane, and one 9808 gallon storage tank is used to store isopentane.

B) The regulated substances handled at this facility are isobutane and isopentane.

C) The maximum amount of these materials stored at this facility is 115,300 pounds. 

3) General accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps

This manufacturing facility complies wi

th the EPA's Accident Prevention Rule and with all applicable State Codes and Regulations. This facility was designed in accordance with NFPA-58 and NFPA -30.  As part of our Corporate Injury Illness and Prevention Plan all employees receive training covering the following aspects of health and safety; safety philosophy, general safety rules, reporting safety hazards, emergency procedures and hazardous communications. In addition to the training received upon employment, further training is given if any employee is exposed to a hazard previously unrecognized, or if any employee is reassigned to a job which exposes them to new hazards. Our Corporate Hazard Communication Plan, which is located in our safety manual, contains safe work practices, descriptions of the use and care of personal protective equipment, and emergency procedures in case of spills or releases. Emergency and first-aid procedures are also covered.    

4) Five year accident history  

There have been no releases at this facility during this period.

5) The emergency response program

This facility's Emergency response program is based upon the NPGA's LP-Gas Handbook. 

6) Planned changes to improve safety

Monthly safety inspections are conducted at this facility and safety deficiencies are corrected as they occur. No major upgrades to this facility are planned at this time.
